awd_titl_txt: SaTC: Expanding Research Frontiers with a Next-Generation Anonymous Communication Experimentation (ACE) Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to expand research frontiers through system deployment has been hindered by a lack of experimentation frameworks that can be used to safely and accurately evaluate new algorithms and network protocols at scale.  This is particularly true for anonymous communication systems, which are generally understood to be among the most secure ways to communicate online, but are difficult to experiment with because (1) they are designed to be resistent to observation and (2) experiments must be crafted very carefully to ensure they do not endanger the systems' users.  This project develops the Anonymous Communication Experimentation (ACE) framework, a novel open-source software platform that enables privacy researchers to better understand and experiment with anonymity systems.  ACE supports the construction of large, realistic, and high fidelity simulations of anonymity networks.  ACE allows researchers to run existing software on top of a virtualized network, allowing them to safely and accurately evaluate the effectiveness of new attacks and defenses, and experiment with new protocols and algorithms before they are deployed in live networks.

This project aims to promote the development of new algorithms and techniques for more robust and private communication by providing a framework for development and testing.  ACE significantly advances the state-of-the-art in network simulation by providing: (1) an application emulation component to facilitate the execution of language-agnostic processes in support of website fingerprinting and censorship circumvention research; (2) a lightweight network simulation component that allows dynamic changes in support of location- and network-aware anonymous communication; (3) an interposition component to hook together the emulated processes with the simulated network; (4) a deterministic simulated virtual kernel that emulates Linux system calls; and (5) parallel and distributed execution components to ensure that ACE is accessible to universities and research labs that lack large server infrastructure.  We will also develop a user interface, a toolkit to model inputs and visualize outputs, and a data repository to share and archive results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anonymous communication systems are generally understood to be among the most secure methods to communicate online.  They protect not only communication content, but also metadata (for example, who communicated with whom), which can otherwise reveal a significant amount about the communicating parties even if the content itself cannot be read. 

 

Unfortunately, the ability to advance the science of anonymous and private communication has been hindered by a lack of experimentation frameworks that can be used to safely and accurately evaluate new algorithms and protocols at scale.  Performing experiments on “live” networks can endanger the users that depend on them.  The use of simulators avoids putting real-world users at risk, but existing simulators lack the capability for high-fidelity experiments that are useful for predicting how research prototypes will behave when actually deployed.

 

This project entailed the design and construction of a novel software framework, Anonymous Communication Experimentation (ACE), that enables high-fidelity and repeatable simulations of distributed systems such as anonymity networks.  ACE, which has been incorporated into the Shadow simulator (see https://shadow.github.io/), allows researchers to directly execute unmodified software and run applications as normal operating system processes.  By supporting the general execution of applications (e.g., network servers, web browsers, etc.), ACE supports software independent of the programming language chosen by developers.  ACE features a lightweight network simulation component that allows applications to communicate with one another through the ACE framework rather than over the Internet.  Finally, ACE features a deterministic discrete-event engine that ensures that research results can be independently and identically reproduced and verified across research labs.

 

Our simulator, associated tools, documentation, and examples are all available for free (see https://shadow.github.io/).  Research groups throughout both academia and industry have used our framework to perform safe and accurate simulations of distributed systems. 

 

Intellectual Merits.  The project focused on the development of a software framework, the architecture of which is a novel contribution in itself.  ACE is the first network experimentation system that runs applications directly as OS processes that are connected and controlled through a simulation backend to improve scalability and reproducibility.  ACE facilitates a rapid expansion of research output as it allows CISE researchers to more easily advance research agendas that were otherwise hindered by a lack of experimentation support.  Although we anticipate much broader impact, ACE is particularly well-suited to advance research on (1) location- and network-aware anonymous communication, (2) website fingerprinting attacks and defenses, and (3) censorship circumvention protocols.  More generally, ACE allows for improved experimentation and analysis of system security and performance in realistic settings against realistic adversaries.

 

Broader Impacts.  Securely and privately communicating is of tremendous interest to organizations and individuals seeking to freely access and disseminate information. This project significantly improved the ability to communicate privately online by providing a framework with which CISE community members can continue to conduct innovative research that improves the design of anonymous communication systems.  The software developed as part of the ACE framework has been released as open-source software with permissive licenses, and has already been used by multiple research groups to help conduct their research.
